Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Religious Expression at Work

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Member of religious groups sometimes perceive and experience hostility and discrimination at work. It is important to understand the complexities of such work experiences because the workplace is a primary setting in which social group assimilation and integration occur. Work also is the primary vehicle through which most people realize social opportunity and upward mobility. Some workers make their religious affiliations visible through clothing and/or other aspects of personal appearance. This project examines how the visibility of religious identities affects professional women and men in the workplace. This project has three goals. First, the project will examine gendered differences in religious expression within the workplace. Second, it will determine how those who signify religious expression at work navigate career advancement. Third, it will explore the strategies such workers use to accommodate/challenge workplace expectations that may be affected by their religious expression. Findings from this research will help policy makers and employers create public policy and constructive workplace practices to address inequalities and discrimination based upon religious expression at work. As such, findings are relevant to enforcement of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 that prohibits discrimination at many workplaces based on characteristics such as race, religion and sex.

This project uses 60 qualitative interviews to compare three sets of employees in professional jobs: 20 women who signify religious affiliation at work, 20 women who do not signify religious affiliation at work, and 20 men who signify religious affiliation at work. Respondents will be drawn from a variety of professional fields, and identified through a combination of personal contacts and snowball sampling. Interview questions include educational background, age, marital status, average hours worked, income, and work history. Additional questions will probe for reasons behind their decisions to either signify or not signify religious identity at work. Interview data will be subjected to open coding to derive themes present in the data using NVIVO to manage transcripts and data analysis. Findings will inform sociological theory related to religious expression at work, as well as gender differences in workplace treatment among professionals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this study is to examine how the visibility of religious identities affects professional women and men in the workplace. Within the U.S., Muslims are often painted by negative images. Thus, when workers make their religious affiliations visible through clothing and/or other aspects of personal appearance, they may experience mistreatment. The project uses 84 qualitative interviews to compare three sets of employees:  33 Muslim women who veil, 26 Muslim women who do not veil, and 25 Muslim men. There are four research objectives. First, the study documents how non-group members uses key ?signifiers? of religious identity to identify Muslim men and women in US workplaces. Second, it details the ways Muslims respond to heightened religious visibility. Third, it analyzes promotional opportunities among workers. Last, the study illustrates how gender issues become more salient within workplaces bound to immigrant communities. 

There are three major intellectual merit contributions. First, findings bridge the theoretical work of orientalism with work on racial formation. Both explain the historical and social conditions that have created negative and sometimes extreme images of Muslims within US society. Chapter 1 details how the racial and gender signifiers rooted in orientalism (i.e. the hijab or dark-skinned and bearded men) emerge at work. Signifiers follow Muslims into their careers shaping relationships, affecting work goals, and forcing workers to confront anti-Muslim hostility and discrimination. A racial hierarchy develops among Muslims, with those Muslims who ?pass? as white at the top of this hierarchy. Darker skin/beards, Muslim names, and types of dress code (the hijab) frame subgroup experiences, adversely affecting how experiences with anti-Muslim hostility unfold.

Second, this work supports theories of gendered organizations. In terms of power and gender, workplace scholars center gender as an organizing principle within work organizations to show how gender inequality occurs. Chapter 4 findings illustrate how gender issues become more salient when workplaces are located within the boundaries of immigrant communities. More specifically, issues of sexual harassment, sexism, and gender discrimination emerge in industries such as real estate and lending. The chapter also compares the experiences of women working outside ethnic communities, whose experiences with sexual harassment center on orientalist imagery of Muslim women as untouchable, exotic, or fetishized, with women working within immigrant communities, where experiences often draw on cultural or religious themes commonly found in their own communities.

Third, this study fills the gap within scholarship that addresses US Arab/Muslim experiences. Workplace research that centers Muslim identities is far more limited. This study expands on the empirical work of Wingfield on partial tokenization and the racialization of the glass escalator in largely white-dominated occupations (2013). Chapter 3 details how Muslims face barriers to networking, confront negative performance reviews, and face glass ceilings and/or career stalls. While men can face these issues, barriers to advancement systematically follow women. Women who veil are often steered into specific career paths or denied larger projects that could help with advancement. Whereas Wingfield argues that scholars must consider intersections of gender and race, the findings of this study indicate that scholars must be sensitive to religion alongside gender and race when examining subgroup differences.

Broader impacts of this study center on the dissemination of these findings using my position as an academic scholar and the potential for policy changes. Using the findings in the classroom will encourage cross-cultural exchanges between students of different backgrounds by offering an account of experiences that often go unheard in teaching establishments Arab and Muslim students often struggle to hear their own histories within scholarship and classrooms. For example, findings from chapter 4 articulate the unique experiences of Muslim workers, including forms of cultural negotiations and expectations of religious expression at work, when it comes to working within their own communities. Similarly, issues of sexual harassment, sexism, and gender discrimination addressed in this chapter often go unheard within immigrant communities.

In addition, this study could affect policy. Finding show that in the twenty years since 9/11, Muslim workers still face scrutiny any time Middle Eastern issues unfold, face perceptions that they are less educated and not fit for promotion. Chapter 1 describes the limitations of religious accommodation policies when workplace culture encourages or ignores anti-Muslim hostility. Chapter 2 discusses how assumptions about their skillset, alongside mainstream views of their religion, push them to be highly efficient to avoid extra scrutiny. Chapter 3 offers an overview of how career trajectories stall due to heightened visibility. Findings indicate that such treatment affects worker retention and discrimination claims. Policymakers and employers can use the study findings to create public policy and constructive workplace practices that address inequalities and discrimination based upon the findings addressed in this study. As such, findings are relevant to enforcement of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 that prohibits discrimination at work based on race, religion and sex.
